trainingData.config:
expectations:
  - ideal: Each bus is identical and has 30 seats, which indicates uniformity.
    features:
      bad:
        - "different|differ|unequal|(\b(isn't|not)\b.*(same|equal))"
        - different
      good:
        - bus|seat(s)|30
        - \040same|identical|equal|uniform
  - ideal: The number of buses and seats are variable quantities and change together.
    features:
      bad:
        - not\040change\040together
        - "\b(not|isn't|no|without)\b.*\b(related|relationship|change)\b"
      good:
        - "(covary|covariance|co-variance|co-vary)|\b(same|equal|together|30)\b\
          .*\b(change|increase|up|grow|vary|rate)\b|(increase|change|grow|up|va\
          ry|rate).*(same|together|equal|30)"
  - ideal: The ratio of the number of buses to seats is constant, indicating
      invariance.
    features:
      bad:
        - not\040multiples
      good:
        - ((same|invariance|invariant|fixed|constant|30).*(multiple|ratio|number|unit\040rate))|1:30
  - ideal: The relationship between the number of buses and seats is proportional.
    features:
      bad:
        - "\b(no|not|isn't|hasn't|never|without)\b.*proportion"
      good:
        - proportion
question: Buses-R-Us makes school buses with 30 seats. As the company makes more
  buses, do the number of buses and the number of seats have a proportional
  relationship? Explain why or why not.
trainingData.training:
